Is the Wheel of Ghosts an Ancient Observatory? New Study Suggests Otherwise - Gadgets 360
summary:
Is the Wheel of Ghosts an Ancient Observatory? New Study Suggests Otherwise

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: Gadgets 360

The ancient Rujm el-Hiri site, known as the 'Wheel of Ghosts,' has been reassessed, leading researchers to question its identification as an astronomical observatory due to significant geodynamic changes over millions of years.

Geophysical Insights Challenge Established Theories

The study reveals that movements over 150 million years have altered the site's alignment, straying from celestial patterns. Led by Dr. Olga Khabarova and Prof. Lev Eppelbaum, the researchers concluded that historical interpretations regarding its orientation do not align with solstices or other astronomical markers.

Advanced Techniques Reveal Archaeological Landscape

Through geomagnetic analysis and satellite technology, the team documented archaeological features near the Sea of Galilee. Unique circular structures alongside burial mounds indicate potential agricultural uses rather than ceremonial roles.

A Broader Perspective on Rujm el-Hiri's Role

Dr. Michal Birkenfeld stated that this research enriches the understanding of ancient life, encouraging further exploration of community-environment interactions.

Catch the latest updates at our CES 2025 hub.
newTitle: Is the Wheel of Ghosts an Ancient Observatory? New Study Suggests Otherwise

As the US and China race to the moon, these loopholes in space law could cause conflict - Phys.org
summary:
As the US and China race to the moon, these loopholes in space law could cause conflict

Date: January 6, 2025 Source: The Conversation

As the US and China prepare for lunar bases, potential disputes over resources and claims could arise due to existing space laws.

  • Both nations plan to establish long-term bases on the moon.
  • Disputes might emerge regarding the location of lunar bases and resource extraction.
  • International space law is complex, with various treaties governing exploration rights.
  • The Outer Space Treaty states space is free for exploration by all states.
  • The Moon Agreement restricts ownership of lunar resources but is not signed by major spacefaring nations.
  • The Artemis Accords aim to establish guidelines for lunar resource use.
  • Legal responsibility for pollution applies even as spacecraft travel beyond our solar system.
"Countries will want to extract this ice because it can be turned into rocket fuel for onward journeys and for life support... the prospect of 'space water wars' is actually nearer..."

This article explores the implications of space law as nations aim for a new space race, highlighting the urgent need for clear regulations to prevent conflict over extraterrestrial resources.
newTitle: US and China Face Legal Challenges in Lunar Exploration

title: MIT Technology Review Releases the 2025 list of 10 Breakthrough Technologies - IT News Online
Belt It Out - Hackster.io
summary:
Advancements in Robotic Gripping Technology

Publication Date: 2025-01-01 Source: TechXplore

The development of a new robotic gripper by researchers at Seoul National University promises to enhance the efficiency of robotic operations by allowing robots to handle multiple objects simultaneously.

  • Existing robotic systems struggle with precise manipulation of multiple objects, whereas humans can perform this task effortlessly.
  • The new robotic hand employs a dual system: fingers for grasping and conveyor belts for transporting items.
  • Trials demonstrated up to 34% time savings and up to 71% reductions in travel distances for robotic arms.
  • This design approach focuses on functionality rather than complex mimicry of human movements.
"The efficiency gains of this novel robotic system were demonstrated in both commercial and domestic trials."

This development represents a significant step toward creating more functional and versatile robots for various applications.

Chang'e-5 samples provide evidence that moon had magnetic field 2 billion years ago - Phys.org
summary:
Chang'e-5 samples provide evidence that moon had magnetic field 2 billion years ago

Publication Date: January 6, 2025

Source: Science X Network

A large team of researchers at the Chinese Academy of Sciences has found evidence that suggests the moon had a magnetic field around 2 billion years ago, based on studies of rock samples returned by the Chang'e-5 lunar mission.

  • The research analyzed lunar rock samples to investigate the moon's magnetic field history.
  • The moon, currently lacking a global magnetic field, had a weak field generated by thermomechanical convection in its interior.
  • Past missions suggested the moon had a magnetic field approximately 4 billion years ago; this study extends the timeline to 2 billion years ago.
  • The magnetic field measurements indicated values between 2,000 to 4,000 nanoteslas, suggesting longer volcanic activity and potential for ancient water.
The moon's magnetic field would have shielded water on the surface from solar wind, preserving it in shadowed regions.

This discovery enhances our understanding of the moon's geological history and its internal processes.
newTitle: Chang'e-5 Samples Reveal Moon's Ancient Magnetic Field

title: 10 striking images of galaxies captured by NASA - DNA India
summary:
10 Striking Images of Galaxies Captured by NASA

Date: Jan 6, 2025

Source: DNA

This article showcases breathtaking images of various galaxies captured by NASA, highlighting their beauty and unique characteristics.

  • MCG-01-24-014 is a bright spiral galaxy located about 275 million light-years from Earth.
  • IC 5332 is captured face-on and is around 30 million light-years away in the Sculptor constellation.
  • The tranquil spiral galaxy UGC 12295 shows stunning cosmic beauty.
  • Jellyfish galaxy JO206 exhibits an impressive star-forming disc surrounded by dust.
  • A galaxy in Pisces dances with filaments spiraling around its supermassive black hole.
  • A barred spiral galaxy active since 1992 has hosted three supernovae.
  • Caldwell 5, located in the Camelopardalis constellation, was discovered in 1895.
  • NASA's work brings these spectacular images to the public eye.
"Source: NASA"

The images not only showcase the stunning beauty of galaxies but also deepen our understanding of these magnificent cosmic structures.
newTitle: 10 Striking Images of Galaxies Captured by NASA

title: There’s still time to catch the stunning Quadrantids meteor shower - Digital Trends
summary:
There’s still time to catch the stunning Quadrantids meteor shower

Publication Date: January 2024 | Source: Digital Trends

The Quadrantids meteor shower, one of the finest meteor showers, is visible throughout early January and will end on January 12. This article offers tips on how to catch this stunning display.

  • The meteor shower is best viewed on the West Coast of the U.S. and in the Pacific region.
  • Robert Massey from the Royal Astronomical Society notes that a thin crescent moon allows for better visibility this year.
  • The Quadrantids are associated with the near-Earth asteroid 2003 EH1, with debris burning up as meteors.
  • During the peak, up to 70 to 80 meteors can be seen per hour, including a notable number of bright fireballs.
  • To view the shower, find a dark spot away from city lights and avoid using binoculars or telescopes for a wider view.
“They have a pretty strong intensity if you happen to be in the right place at the right time…” - Robert Massey

Don't miss out on this New Year treat; enjoy the meteor shower with good weather and dark skies!
newTitle: Experience the Spectacular Quadrantids Meteor Shower Before It Ends

title: An abundant phytoplankton feeds a global network of marine microbes - Phys.org
Research Shows Twin Births Were Common in Ancient Primate Evolution - Gadgets 360
summary:
Research Shows Twin Births Were Common in Ancient Primate Evolution

Publication Date: Unknown | Source: Gadgets 360

This article explores a study which reveals that ancient primates predominantly gave birth to twins, a stark contrast to modern patterns of singleton births. Researchers reconstructed primate reproductive history, suggesting this shift occurred due to evolutionary advantages.

  • Twin births were once standard among ancient primates.
  • The transition to singleton births occurred at least 50 million years ago, coinciding with increased primate brain and body size.
  • Understanding this evolution aids in studying modern reproductive dynamics.
“This historical context can provide insights into the biological and social dynamics of reproduction.”

The findings emphasize the lasting impact of evolutionary pressures on reproductive strategies over millions of years.
newTitle: Research Shows Twin Births Were Common in Ancient Primate Evolution

title: A New Approach to Neuromorphic Computing - AZoOptics
summary:
A New Approach to Neuromorphic Computing

Published on: [Publication Date]
Source: [Source Name]

Scientists led by Professor Nazek El-Atab at KAUST have created a MOSCap device that mimics neuron-like adaptive behavior and memory retention using Hafnium diselenide (HfSe2). Their study showcases advancements in neuromorphic computing.

  • The separation of sensing, processing, and memory in traditional systems causes inefficiencies.
  • Neuromorphic computing combines these functions into a single device, enhancing efficiency.
  • Incorporation of HfSe2 nanosheets allows unique data retention and adaptability.
  • Real-world tests show memory retention stability under high temperatures.
  • Potential applications include astronomy for detecting exoplanets.
“The memory window of the device remained above the failure threshold for 106 seconds at 60–80 °C.”

This discovery represents a significant improvement in neuromorphic technology, highlighting its potential to develop systems that mimic the dynamic learning processes of biological neurons.
newTitle: A New Approach to Neuromorphic Computing

Discovering “Avalanching” Nanocrystals with Revolutionary Switching Capabilities - AZoNano
summary:
Discovering “Avalanching” Nanocrystals with Revolutionary Switching Capabilities

Date: Not specified, Source: Oregon State University

Scientists at Oregon State University have identified luminescent nanocrystals that can quickly switch between light and dark states, which holds potential for advancements in optical computing and memory technologies.

  • The study was published in Nature Photonics.
  • Avalanching nanocrystals exhibit highly non-linear light emission properties.
  • Controlled by lasers, these nanocrystals mimic electronic transistor behavior.
  • Research could lead to more efficient optical communication and artificial intelligence processing.

“The extraordinary switching and memory capabilities of these nanocrystals may one day become integral to optical computing…” - Artiom Skripka, Assistant Professor, Oregon State University

These nanocrystals may be key in reducing energy consumption in electronic devices and data centers as they can operate on low power.

In conclusion, while the findings are promising, further research is necessary for real-world applications.
newTitle: Scientists Discover Nanocrystals with Unique Light-Switching Abilities

title: SpaceX aims to launch 1st Starlink satellites of 2025 today, and you can watch live - Space.com
A New Catalyst for Efficient CO2 Conversion - AZoM
summary:
A New Catalyst for Efficient CO2 Conversion

Date: 2024 Source: Nature Synthesis

Researchers have developed a copper-based catalyst that converts carbon dioxide to acetaldehyde with 92% efficiency, providing a sustainable alternative to traditional methods.

  • The catalyst was created by a public-private consortium led by Cedric David Koolen and others.
  • Acetaldehyde is primarily derived from ethylene, a process with a significant carbon footprint.
  • This new electrochemical reduction method effectively addresses CO2 emissions while producing valuable chemicals.
  • The catalyst shows promise for scalability and cost-effectiveness in industrial applications.
  • During testing, it maintained performance and selectivity over multiple cycles.

The Wacker process effectively hasn’t changed in the past 60 years. It is still based on the same basic chemistry. The time was ripe for a green breakthrough. - Cedric David Koolen

This breakthrough could transform industries reliant on acetaldehyde, including pharmaceuticals and agriculture, while reducing reliance on fossil fuels.
newTitle: A New Catalyst for Efficient CO2 Conversion
